Message.Title: Hot news: HP Slate 21 AIO is a 21-inch Android tablet (2nd Tegra 4 tablet by HP)
Message.Msg: SOURCE: CNET by John Chan 24 June 2013 2:31pm SGT At its HP World Tour event in Beijing, the company announced the HP Slate 21 all-in-one (AIO) Android tablet. Sporting a 21.5-inch touchscreen display, this device is meant for desktop use, and can be propped up with a kickstand on the back. Inside, the HP Slate 21 AIO runs on the Nvidia Tegra 4 processor, which promises better graphics performance compared with the older Tegra 3. This should come in handy when playing games on the device, which is appropriate given it's meant to be a home entertainment product. We first heard about the Slate 21 when benchmark results appeared online earlier this year. HP has not given the availability and pricing of the new AIO, but said local information will be available when the Slate 21 is launched in each country. ______ PS: HP'a first Tegra 4 tablet was announced in May: HP SlateBook X2 features a 10 convertible tablet to be released in August. PPS: The author of this news article is a CNET editor, not some loose-talking, "paid by clicks" blogger.....

Message.Title: Some place else you won't see Tegra 4, The Next Nexus 7.
Message.Msg: "Asus-made 2nd gen new Nexus 7 peeks out from FCC filing Thanks, FCC! By Michael Rougeau June 17th Asus-made 2nd gen new Nexus 7 peeks out from FCC filing Google Nexus 7 2: Like this, but better? The next-gen Google Nexus 7 could indeed arrive soon, like the rumors say. And the kicker is that the new Nexus 7 will be made by Asus, if a recent FCC filing is any indication. The Federal Communications Commission published a listing that appears to show the full specs for the Nexus 7 2 under the model numbers K008 and K009. Android Authority delves into the legitimacy of the filing and the likelihood of it being the Nexus 7 2, but suffice to say it's looking likely. So let's get on to the specs, shall we? You're welcome The new Google Nexus 7 2 by Asus appears to sport a significant upgrade in the display department, up to 1080p, and more memory at 2GB. It looks like Asus is also switching the new Nexus 7 from Nvidia's Tegra 3 to Qualcomm's Snapdragon S4 PRO. The camera situation is also upgraded from 1.2 megapixels to 5 megapixels on the back, and with a new 1.3-megapixel snapper on the front. NFC, LTE and wireless charging are all new as well, not to mention Android 4.3 out of the box." source: techradar

Message.Title: NVIDIA retail Shield in action
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Fudzilla Short demo by Nvidia VP And it finally happened. After numerous beta version of Nvidia’s Shield console, we were lucky enough to see the final retail version demonstrated by Nvidia's Vice president of corporate marketing Ujesh Desai. We didn’t really spent days with the console, we had a few minutes with this busy man, but it was enough to get a first-hand impression. Ujesh demonstrated that he is a skilled first person shooter player and he showed us how Dead Trigger 2 looks on the final version of the console. The graphics are better than anything we saw on Android so far, and the game is worth of few bucks when it comes out. We also had a chance to see Virtual Tennis and this Android game from the Play Store also looked nice. It was easy to navigate through to Android 4.2.2 and the speaker quality is quite nice. You can use this small device to play some loud music outside, which can’t be said of most tablets, let alone smartphones. We liked the build quality and that Nvidia used a matte black finish that doesn’t really attract finger smudges. In the video, Ujesh demonstrated taking off the magnetic custom tag removal and magnet powered attaching it back. It looks really nice and works well. We also mentioned battery life and Ujesh went in detail about the console's battery life, with some optimistic figures. With gaming PC streaming you should expect 10 to 12 hours, because all the heavy lifting is done on the desktop that sends the end result as a compressed H.264 HD video. If you are doing basic Android gaming, such as some of the older Tegra 3 games, you should expect six to eight hours battery life. With games optimised for Tegra 4 with a lot of visual effects, you can expect 4 to 5 hours, claims Ujesh.

Message.Title: Intel likelihood of fabbing for Apple rises, says analyst
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Lazard Capital via Barrons Lazard Capital semiconductor analyst Daniel Amir today reiterated a Buy rating on shares of Intel (INTC), writing that the chances of the company becoming a contract chip maker for Apple (AAPL) are more likely than they have in past. Based on our recent checks across the supply channel, we highlight the impact and reasons why a widely anticipated deal with Apple as a potential foundry customer is becoming more likely,” writes Amir. Among the factors Amir includes are newly installed CEO Brian Krzanich being more open to the prospect of Apple as a foundry customer; having the technology edge in manufacturing over contract foundry Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM); having some excess capacity in new factories that will be rolling out in the next two years; and having already dedicated resources to contract work for other large customers. _____ On the flip side, however, I doubt Apple would allow Intel a hefty gross margin if deal materializes. We all know how Cook drives a hard bargain and have historically skimmed all its component suppliers.

Message.Title: Intel's 2013 growth projection doesn't add up, says Bernstein analyst
Message.Msg: Bernstein Research‘s Stacy Rasgon today reiterates an Underperform rating on shares of Intel (INTC) and an $18 price target, writing that unit growth projections for the company’s microprocessor sales the latter half of this year are unrealistic, assuming current trends in personal computer sales. Probably, writes Rasgon, Intel is betting not only on its “Core” family of mainstream PC processors, but also on new chips for mobile, such as the forthcoming “Bay Trail“: “We believe the company has high hopes for their forthcoming Bay Trail quad-core Atom chip.” “We hope so too, as the company will need to sell huge amounts of them to achieve growth goals for the year,” he writes. Intel announced on April 16th, following its Q1 report, that it expects revenue growth this year “in the low single digits,” after a decline of 5% or so this quarter. To achieve the year’s target, writes Rasgon, Intel needs to see shipment growth of 12% to 20% in PC microprocessors in the back half of the year. However, “Given atrocious PC results in Q1 (down ~14% YoY, the worst quarter since data collection began), it seems unlikely that this kind of growth could be driven by PCs.” “Rolling normal seasonality out would suggest total PC unit growth down 5-12% YoY, which would suggest unit growth for Intel that is flat, to down 10% YoY in the second half.” Even server microprocessors and mobile chips don’t seem likely to make up the difference, he writes. For server chips to grow by Intel’s suggested “low double digits” this year, the business would have to see 20% or more unit growth the latter part of this year, but “the business has never seen growth on that order for two quarters in a row.” And for mobile, “Intel will need to ship 20-50 MILLION of the chips [Bay Trail, etc.] all in the second half to make up the shortfall from traditional PCs assuming roughly seasonal outlook for Core products.” Rasgon models $53.82 billion in revenue this year, which would be a fraction of 1% growt

Topic.Title: Intel's 2013 growth projection doesn't add up, says Bernstein analyst

Message.Msg: Source article: Barrons just in.

Topic.Title: Intel likelihood of fabbing for Apple rises, says analyst

Message.Msg: Good to have 2 sources... Apple has reportedly reached deal with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world’s largest chip manufacturer, as it continues its efforts to end its business relationship with rival Samsung. According to unnamed sources speaking with Digitimes, Apple has inked a three-year deal with TSMC that will see utilize the company’s foundry services for the upcoming A8, A9 and A9X chipsets. Production of the A8 is supposedly scheduled to begin in small volumes next month for testing, and it will utilize a 20-nanometer process. The A9 and A9X will use 16-nanometer and 10-nanometer processes, respectively, according to the report. Digitimes reported earlier that TSMC will also be building Apple’s A7 processor, which is expected to power the upcoming iPhone 5S. The A8 is then expected to be included in the iPhone 6 and other mobile devices, and the A9 and A9X will be found in Apple’s 2015 and 2016 lineups, respectively.

Message.Title: Update for whosunw as requested: QCOM. BRCM at risk as Samsung cuts S4 outlook
Message.Msg: Wedge analyst put numbers on the sales deficits. SOURCE: Barrons today Brian Blair of Wedge Partners today reflects on the reports of slowing sales of Samsung‘s flagship Galaxy S4 smartphone, which numerous Street observers have attempted in recent weeks to quantify. Writes Blair, the reported initial sales of 10 million of the device were below even greater expectations on the part of the South Korean giant: ""While 10 million units was an impressive number, particularly given that it was only one Samsung SKU, we understood at the time that the 10 million reported was much lower than Samsung’s own target of 14 – 15 million units for that same period [...] To start, we believe Samsung’s original 1-year unit projection for the S4 was initially in the 100 million unit range. We now believe that number has been cut 10-15 million, and is now in the 85-90 million unit range for the first 12 months. We also estimate that Q3 S4 production had been in the 40 million unit range, but has been cut to approximately 30 million units or roughly 3.5 million less per month for the September quarter. In addition to Galaxy unit declines, iPhone units from June to September quarters over the last two years have been down ~16% sequentially to flat last year. We believe a 5-10% sequential downtick in iPhone units is likely. " Reasons, Blair writes, range from “saturation of high end smartphones in first world markets” to greater competition from devices such as HTC‘s “HTC One” device, also recently released; to “a lengthening in the replacement cycle for smartphone users, who are keeping existing handsets for longer periods of time (longer than 1-2 yrs. The slowing, if true, puts a “cap” on the upside for chip makers, including Broadcom (BRCM), Qualcomm, Skyworka, ST Microelectronics, Maxim, and Synaptics. Broadcom and Qualcomm have the most exposure to the S4, providing NFC, WiFi, and GPS chips in BCOM’s case; wireless modem, power management, and the app SoC in QCOM's case.....

Message.Title: "Toshiba REGZA AT703 is the world’s first Tegra 4 based tablet to go on sale"
Message.Msg: "Toshiba REGZA AT703 is the world’s first Tegra 4 based tablet to go on sale" "Say hello to the Toshiba REGZA AT703, the world’s first Tegra 4 based smart device (tablet) to go on sale. Looks like Toshiba beat everyone to the (non-existent) race of releasing a Tegra 4 powered product, a tablet in this case, to the market. The Toshiba REGZA AT703 tablet packs Nvidia’s (failed) Tegra 4 SoC. The four ARM Cortex A15 cores are clocked at 1.8 GHz, a far cry from the 2 GHz+ core clock speeds that Cortex A15 products were initially planned to be (they turned out to be major power hogs). Enough with the rant, Toshiba wasn’t actually the first company to announce a Tegra 4 based product. HP beat competition by announcing a Tegra 4 based tablet from its own stable, but Toshiba managed to put their own product into the market, at least in Japan, before anybody else. Toshiba REGZA AT703 specifications: Nvidia Tegra 4 Chipset 1.8 GHz Quad-Core ARM Cortex A15 GPU 72-core GeForce GPU 2 GB RAM 10.1-inch WQXGA (2560 x 1600) Display 8 MP Rear, 1.3 MP Front Camera 32 GB Internal Storage, Micro SD Card Slot Electrostatic Touch Stylus Bluetooth 4.0, 802.11 a/b/g/n/ac Wi-Fi Dimensions: 60.7 x 178.9 x 10.5mm Weight: 671 Grams Android 4.2 Jelly Bean" source: vr-zpne And what do they call Tegra 4 in this article spreading the good news? lol "The Toshiba REGZA AT703 tablet packs Nvidia’s (failed) Tegra 4 SoC."
